>I use this method as well [see below]. Seems least error prone.

Me too. I see nothing wrong with that method. It's the simplest thing that
could possibly work.  Nice without clutter.

The original question from Mike Duffy was :

>The Junit.org site has an FAQ section
>(http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm) with the following
>question: How do I implement a test case for a thrown exception?
>The answer they give is not completely correct because it does not
>account for the possiblility that another exception could be thrown.

But this is not true. The code is correct and does account for the
possibility of another thrown exception : it will be catched by the
framework and the test will fail (has an error). Still, the FAQ could be
improved by explaining this and by adding a "throws Exception" clause like
the code below, suggested by rainsber:

mathieu.
